children: Unstructured notes on blocks and encodings
describes the meaning of a piece of data in the context of a learning task.
For example, for supervised learning tasks, there is an input block and a target block and we want to learn to predict targets from inputs. Learning to predict a cat/dog label (
) is a supervised image classification task.
A block is not a piece of data itself. Instead it describes the meaning of a piece of data in a context. That a piece of data is a block can be checked using [
. A piece of data for the
block above needs to be one of the labels, so
We can say that a data container is compatible with a learning task if every observation in it is a valid sample of the sample block of the learning task. The sample block for supervised tasks is
from a compatible data container implies that
. This also means that any data stored in blocks must not depend on individual samples; we can store the names of possible classes inside the
block because they are the same across the whole dataset.
We can use blocks to formalize the data processing pipeline.
we want to create pairs of data

and instead we have an encoding step that transforms a sample into representations suitable to train a model on, i.e.
For the above image classification example we have

but we cannot put raw images into a model and get out a class. Instead, the image is converted to an array that includes the color dimension and its values are normalized; and the class label is one-hot encoded. So
. Hence to do training, we need a sample encoding function
, we have an input and want to use a trained model to predict a target, i.e.
. The model is again a mapping
, so we can build the transformation with an encoding step that encodes the input and a decoding step that takes the model output back into a target.
In the classification example we have, written in blocks,
Where do we draw the line between model and data processing? In general, the encoding and decoding steps are
transformations, while the model is a
are reversible transformations that model the non-learnable parts (encoding and decoding) of the data pipeline.
What an encoding does depends on what block is passed in. Most encodings only transform specific blocks. For example, the
, but leaves other blocks unchanged. Encodings are called with

which take in the block and the data. The actual encoding and decoding takes in an additional context argument which can be specialized on to implement different behavior for e.g. training and validation.

mimes.text/html:
summary(data) = "100×100 Array{RGB{Float64},2} with eltype ColorTypes.RGB{Float64}"
summary(encdata) = "100×100×3 Array{Float32, 3}"

encodedblock(enc, Image{2}()) = FastAI.Vision.ImageTensor{2}(3)
decodedblock(enc, ImageTensor{2}(3)) = Image{2}()

children: indicating that it doesn't transform the data. This is overwritten for blocks for which
are implemented to indicate that the data is transformed. Using
Encodings can be applied to tuples of blocks. The default behavior is to apply the encoding to each block separately.
Applying a tuple of encodings will encode the data by applying one encoding after the other. When decoding, the order is reversed.

creates a learning task from blocks and encodings. You define the sample block (recall for supervised tasks this is a tuple of input and target) and a sequence of encodings that are applied to all blocks.
The below example defines the same learning task as
does. The first two encodings only change
expects a sample and just runs the encodings over that, giving us an encoded input

The easiest way to understand how encodings are applied to each block is to use
which print a table of how each encoding is applied successively to each block. Rows where a block is
indicate that the data was transformed by that encoding.
The above tables make it clear what happens during training ("encoding a sample") and inference (encoding an input and "decoding an output"). The more general form
takes in encodings and blocks directly and can be useful for building an understanding of how encodings apply to some blocks.

Since most encodings just operate on a small number of blocks and keep the rest unchanged, applying them to all blocks is usually not a problem. When it is because you want some encoding to apply to a specific block only, you can use
